content.description: Crimpy route following drill marks up and onto hollow flake.
Start sitting on the lip just above a large notch. Climb the lip and topout around the corner.A lower start to this could be added with a lot of landing work.
content.location: This is found on the backside of the large freestanding boulder to the right of Anodyne.

content.description: Start left hand in runnel and right hand crimp. Climb thin and tricky moves to the break. Traverse right to the arete and continue to the top. The direct line is an open project.
content.location:
Hidden in the trees behind the large talus pile in the south quarry. There is an old overgrown access road that leads around the talus pile through the forest.

 GPS: 45.495706, -87.994302

content.description: SDS on two edges (same start as Panacea). Traverse right through a series of slopers and continue up the right arete using a slopey jug and rugged crimp. The slanted rock is used for feet but the large detached block is not.
content.location: Main boulder at the south quarry.

content.description: SDS on two good edges. Climb straight up tricky granite holds. Large detached block is used for feet, but all smaller detached flakes under the boulder are not used.
content.location: Main boulder at the south quarry.

content.description: Easy climb up obvious features left of the drill holes.
content.location: Other side of the south quarry. Can be seen from Snake Oil and Panacea.

content.description: Stand start moving into obvious shelf. Rock a high right foot to a committing mantel for a high right finger bucket. Get feet onto shelf and finish out left
content.location: Right of snake oil in the Aberdeen Quarry South proper. Take ridge line of the quarry and scramble down small talus to the climb.

content.description: A cool crack line partly formed by a big vertical bore hole.  Stand start in an undercling where the bore comes out and climb straight up.
content.location: Between Anodyne and Chris Harrison is a tall slab.  This climbs the crack on the left side of the slab.

content.description: Stand start on a jug rail at head height on the left side of the overhanging wall. Climb up and right using the singular rail feature to gain the right arete, once here enjoy the tall but easier climbing to the top. Certainly one of Wisconsin's best hard lines.
content.location: The striking wall just South and adjacent to the Snake Oil boulder.

content.description: The south quarry has less concentration compared to the north, but the quality of the boulders is high and worth a visit. There is still potential here for some awesome boulders. As with the north quarry, some boulders are only accessible in the winter when the water is frozen.
